comments.commentBody: The Republicans still have a strong presence in the "Northwest Territories," otherwise known as the Great Lakes States: Walker, Kasich, Boehner. But this bedrock of "old" Republicans has never had a great love for the Southern Strategy and the courting of the Old South. Look at the number of Civil War deaths by state. New York maybe be number one, but Ohio, Illiniois and Pennsylvania are right up there. These are the Republicans who need to get their "stuff" together and take their party back.

Well, for the one percenters, their idea of a democracy is one that provides the most benefits to them and it is working quite well, thank you very much!   The problem is for the other 99%, the word democracy is now only a nebulous term that was written in to the original constitution that for some time now, has lost its real meaning.

Here's a news flash for you:  President Obama, although half white and half black, is a bona fide member of the so-called one percent.  He has done far more for the elite than he has done for the poor and middle class.

Though I don't approve of all this money sloshing around in politics (on both sides), and I opposed the Citizen's United decision -- in fact, democracy is about "one man, one vote".

It isn't about money. Nothing about democracy says people can't advertise or promote their own points of view.

Nothing about a lot of rich people spending money keeps YOU from voting. Yet many people do not bother to vote -- not even to register to vote!

You can't blame that on "158 rich people".
And for some reason, we still call it a democracy.  Scary.

Where does it say the Nazi invasion was a myth? The author is referring to the myth of the GREAT and GOOD Soviet Republic and that no one is allowed to speak of the horrors of war.

And why do people feel the urge to always compare us with Russia. This is an author that is doing nothing more than keeping a record of atrocities, sacrifice and suffering endured by the people at the bottom. That's all.

Svetlana is not political. She is interested in the following to quote her: "I am interested in the human being. What happens to him in our time...How does man behave and react."

We have committed our own atrocities and have our own myths - currently white-washed by the "patriotic" right, that thinks we can do no wrong and have a good excuse for all we have done wrong because after all - people of color (Blacks) are, to paraphrase Wm. F. Buckley the inferior race, and our destiny to tame the west overruled any rights native Americans had.
The Golden Rule.  Millionaires never put up their own cash.  Always borrowed and from the public as much as possible.

Well, one thing about billionaires is that they get that way and accumulate their immense wealth often by spending other peoples money, usually the taxpayers.  Add to that, they have this inane ability of, after taking the money, making the taxpayer feel that they should be thankful in giving it to them, especially the billionaires that own sports franchises and want new stadiums.
Tried this tonight and we loved it!  Not hard just took some time.  It helps we had fresh rosemary and thyme in our back yard.

If the best that one can say is that they are not hypocrites, that sounds like damning with faint praise.

If they find the idea of accepting government help in any form so abhorrent, then maybe they should take themselves out of the game.

Dear Prof. Sharma: You are right. Your problem with Kashmir is going on for 60 years now and has become an excruciatingly chronic problem. Nobody knows when the Kashmir problem and cross border insurgency will stop in your region. Exactly in the same way, if ISIS is not defeated  right now, this will also be a chronic problem, like Kashmir, with far more venomous teeth in its jaw. I fully agree with you that there is an urgent need to form a global coalition to defeat ISIS as soon as possible. Thank you.
Romeo Andersson, I appreciate and share your concern for peace and terror free world. Thanks.

With enough opaqueness and techno-legal loopholes in the functioning of regulatory mechanism of the international financial system, and an active support by some states to the Islamic State, it's well nigh impossible to either starve the Islamic State of finances or to wage an effective war against it. The main difficulty being faced in putting together a united international effort against the scourge of terrorism is the lack of a commonly agreed definition of global terrorism and a common will among the nations  to confront it. As such one man's terrorist becomes a freedom fighter for the other. Or, when the cross-border terror strikes India, it's a regional problem,  and when the terror strikes the US it becomes a global phenomenon necessitating a global war against it. It's this duplicity of nations and shadow financial transactions across the borders together with the functioning of a parallel global economy that makes it difficult to fight against the ISIS or other terror outfits.
Being in this country illegally is not a felony, it is a misdemeanor.

Ah, so typical of phony conservatives not to know--or to know and not care--that real american conservatives would never, never, ever, under threat of death or torture to execution of family members or damnation to hell

wrap

themselves

in

the flag.

Trash.

The popular vote in the last presidential election was very much in favor of the Democrats, yet through gerrymandering a GOP-dominated congress prevailed precipitating a deliberate paralysis of government, where a rump is holding the whole place to ransom. It doesn't really jibe with the notion of the US as a global leader with a bunch of gleeful stalwart obstructionists holding court whose sole aim is to thwart Obama's governance with political impunity because their seats are safe. This is an insidious form of plutocracy. It's a sinister development where elements of a ruinous anarchy are now emerging.
My son graduated from Harvard and is a scientist, I have never force him to study anything he didn't like, that's his choice !

Kristof is missing a crucial factor, and one which he certainly knows about: many if not most of the Asian doctors, researchers, etc. did not really take on those occupations by choice but because their parents forced them to do it for "family pride" for "face." That's why there are so many Asian doctors, etc. They were forced into it by their controlling families, and being of Confucian upbringing they usually obey. Same goes for staying at home and studying all day. Do they do it because they enjoy it? No. Their parents forced them to sacrifice every Friday night, every Saturday, every Sunday, so that they can stay home and study and score high on tests. Their families control them, often till the day they die.

My EV is rated at 82 miles to the charge but I actually average around 105. My daily driving is about 30 miles, which means I only need a charge every couple days - easy to do at home overnight. While it is nice to have public chargers, they aren't absolutely essential to me and, I suspect, other EV drivers. Sure, there are several public chargers I can "top off" at while shopping, but none of them are free. I pay $0.11 per kWh at home and most charging stations run 3x-4x that and more.

Although this is our primary car, we have a second ICE car. If we need to go more than 100 miles in a day, we use the other car. Like others, I have found the "Electric Highway" of charging stations to be hit-or-miss as far as being out of service, the wrong "flavor" of plug or already in-use.

When Elon Musk makes an EV that is truly for the common driver his dream of EV over-coming ICE vehicles will be closer reality. As it stands now, TESLA's solution is similar to other exotic brand sports vehicle business models - sell high-end expensive cars to target enthusiasts that can drop over $100k on a work of art that they can drive. Leadership in EV exotics will prove to be TESLA's downfall as he may have been the strongest 'first-to-market' to have sustained business to-date leadership is fleeting as the traditional exotic vehicles manufacturers, that have sliced and diced TESLA's technology to look for marginal improvements, will out-last Elon Musk. I don't think that Silicon Valley or Investors will continue to support an exotic EV builder unless there is a clear and progressive business model to champion the largest market segment. Time is also fleeting.

Where does one buy and service TESLA? I think that being new is fine but eventually some rich owners of TESLA may prefer to keep their vehicles in good working order without too much time involved. Porsche learned that hard lesson when owners got tired of lining up at Porsche limited services for oil changes, tire rotations and regular 'fine-tuning'.

I like Elon Musk and what he has accomplished - like millions of other fans, but even the smartest tools in the shed will not over-come business and market risks associated with high-end EV sales "and services" .
Article is talking about L2, not fast charge. You don't need Tesla to have locking charging handle; even my $3000 SparkEV cannot remove charging handle while fast charging without the electronic key.

The Model 3 is going to be revealed next year. $35,000

EV's lack of service need has spawned the phrase "You only have to replace 6 things. 2 Wiper blades and 4 wheels"

Of course other things may go wrong but with so many less parts than a gas car, they are amazingly reliable. Service needed on them is massively less than the gas cars.

I have a Tesla. With Teslas, no one but the person holding the electronic 'key' can take the charging plug out of the car. And I have never had to wait at any Tesla charging station anywhere in California.
trust a computer programmer to come up with a complicated solution that costs lots of money, and won't work.  A $300 ticket will do the trick.
My take-away:  two-parent families, high expectations, strong work ethic, and a high value on education.   This formula would seem to work for anyone regardless of race or ethnicity.

It's not as bad as it seems. You will charge mostly at home anyway. You can always consider a PHEV....Volt (read some Volt owners FB pages and get a feel for how much Volts love their cars.) BMW is also doing a big push towards PHEVs. Ford has one too. Actually, LA has a decent amount public EV chargers. Do a search on PlugShare.com.

Hardly a paid advocate of the fissile fuel industry. This was a brutally honest article with a lot of involvement by experienced EV owners. This article just exposes a growing pain for the industry and a call for greater infrastructure and civilty among drivers who use public charging. I woul completely agree that most experienced EV drivers was stations to be pay stations. Employers who offer charging as a benefit to their employees need to give the proper attention to rules and ratio of charges and owners need to know their charging strategy before jumping in.

Try shopping at Whole Foods. The customers are much ruder than those at conventional groceries. They think nothing of just stopping their carts in the middle of the aisle and minutely checking the nutritional information of item after item, even though there are people behind them waiting to get through the blocked aisle. It's quite amazing. It's as if they don't recognize the fact that other humans actually exist.

Environmentalists are not motivated by a desire to be kind to the inanimate earth. They are motivated by concern for the unfathomably complex web of life which has evolved into all the unique species which exist today (and are being wiped out at a greater and greater rate). The term "earth" is sometimes used as shorthand for the planet and all of its ecosystems.

But you probably knew that and were just looking for something mean to say about fellow men who think differently from you.
I would have thought that being kind to the earth is also being kind to our fellow man that share the planet with us.
I find it interesting that these electric car owners will go out of their way to be kind to the earth, an inanimate object, yet kindness for their fellow man comes up short in these cases.
Illogical. Build the unicorn pasture first so there's someplace to put the unicorn and provide food for it.
As Elon once said, you've got to build the unicorn before you go building unicorn pastures.

I will never understand the use of a Cuisnart in making a biscuit or pie dough for that matter. However, unless you're putting out the biscuits for the Queen, one can simply gather the left-over pieces together and push them into crooked little mounds and bake. The 2nd best advice I received for biscuits was to never roll the dough out twice.

I don't get what you're saying.
How does Asian success, resulting from hard work, bring about more discrimination?
Please explain.
Asian "success" does not mean discrimination has ended. On the contrary, Asian success, resulting from hard work, has brought with it even more discrimination, especially in education.
To many, many more.
Whoa, everybody, my b-day is on the 14th.  Thanks, meanwhile, for all the pre-wishes.  Warms the cockles of my heart (what are cockles?). In other words, I'm not an octogenarian yet! Patience!
Leapy, it takes one to know two.

and Elke

Enjoy all the festivities, surrounded by family and friends. Be assured we all wish we could be there with you.

Immigrants to America who are trying to better their condition in life must be careful not to acquire certain typically American values too quickly. A good part of the conventional commercially propagated American set of wishes and hopes is poison, and leads to dependency. This is the result of conscious effort on the part of the merchandisers who try to create a gullible and malleable consuming population.

To be a member of a religion or ethnic group that is automatically separated from this sort of americanization is obviously a help. Asians now, Jews in earlier times, were not immediately welcomed into the larger society and had time to find out which parts of it were beneficial and which were harmful.

African-Americans, to their misfortune, are the quintessential Americans, brought here many generations ago and exposed from the first to the less desirable forces in society. They have less resistance to the things that will harm them and suffer accordingly. West Indians on average know better, despite a similar ethnic background. They have not been in the pressure cooker as long.

We need to be honest with ourselves when considering immigrants and how they join us in inhabiting this continent. Do we want them to have habits of independence, or are we trying to recruit them to the set of those who work so that we don't have to? If we can deal directly with ourselves when considering this question, those who are here and those who are coming will all benefit.

My sentiments also, as I have postulated in previous posts.

They have made themselves the enemy.

The Democrats are only slightly---very slightly better.  In 2008, when they had the White House, and the Congress, did they restore the Post Office as required by the Constitution?  No.  Did they fund Amtrak so we can have high-speed rail instead of choo-choo trains?  No.  Did they restore Glass-Steagall?  No.  Wake me when there's a political party that wants to work Mon-Fri, 9-5, for the good of the nation, regardless of the risks to their personal ambitions.

For years the Republican Party has deliberately demonized government the way it used to go after the Soviet Union. It's also catered to an increasingly radicalized base, promising them it would 'take their country back'. It's unleashed the power of Big Money in order to win elections, and gerrymandered voting districts to make as many of the Red as they can get away with while also blowing away voting rights. The results?

Having made government the enemy, they can't be in it and run it without being accused of being traitors to the cause. (So much for being a governor or a member of Congress.) They've made all kinds of promises they can't keep - and their base can't understand why, if they control Congress, they haven't delivered. Big Money is now free to back any candidate it wants to buy to the point where the party no longer controls election purse strings. And, since party members are coming from safe districts, all they have to worry about is pleasing the voters back home, not following the party line if it would anger that base.

The Republicans have painted themselves into a corner.

Ted Cruz may be sitting pretty, but the only way he can rise to power is to finalize the destruction of the party and the government. And he's just the egomaniac to do it. You haven't begun to see ugly yet.

The sooner everyone realizes the Republican Party is now completely dysfunctional if not outright crazy, the better.

Ian: Usually, request for bids would mention the need for government guarantees, so the U.S. (before Ex-Im Bank demise) and Euro/Japan/Korean competitirs were on an even footing. For that matter, Ex-Im Bank had always been less aggressive than its foreign equivalents.
